item.title: Post Sit Thoughts
item.description: I recently sat a ten day silent meditation retreat. Here are some thoughts that continued to surface throughout the retreat. Before I left I saw this quote by Rene Girard: “The sickest ones are those who are overly concerned with the sickness of others.” This struck me when I saw it becauseÂ I admit being concerned with what I perceive as a sickness in the modern social landscape of America. It was implying that I was more sick than the targets of my criticism.

item.title: What Jesus meant, maybe
item.description: There are these moments I have in yoga when I am dying. It feels like death. I cannot breath. I am dizzy. My chest is pounding. I want to quit. I want to leave the room. I feel alone. I feel so terrible. I start to feel pity for myself. All of my attention falls into the chasm of my own pain and suffering. And not only that, I start to have feelings about that pain and suffering, I start to have negative feelings about the feelings.

item.title: Never ending story
item.description: The question of where things come from is solved. There is no doubt about how to realize things in the world. What is needed is brought into existence in the world when it is needed. Until then it waits as potential. Until then, energy goes into the imagination and creation of what is to come. The relationship with this process grows stronger and stronger. It is the connection to this process that sustains life.

item.title: My Father's son
item.description: I am my father’ son. For a very long time, I’ve been unable to accept this. My father was a complicated person. He was human, with good and not so good qualities. It is also the case that he was not around. As far as what part of me is from him and what is from my mom, it was always a bit of a process of elimination and some guess work.

item.title: Notes on Parallelism and Concurrency
item.description: I’ve been on a number of interviews in the past two months. I’ve got another coming up and in order to prepare I want to review some additional python, programming and computer architecture topics. Concurrency in Computer science is when different parts or units of a program/algortihm can be executed out-of-order or partially out of order. The opposite of concurrent execution is serial execution where each part or unit must be executed in order.

item.title: Cross Validation in Finance
item.description: Cross validation is used to determine the generalization error of an ML algorithm. It is designed to prevent overfitting. Cross-Validation in ML ML algorithms attempt to learn the structure of the data (training data) so that we can infer the same structure on unseen data (test data). Training and testing on the same dataset will yield very high levels of prediction precision. This is what file-lossy algos do. They can summarize data with extreme fidelity, yet have zero forecasting power.

item.title: Ensemble Methods
item.description: Chapter 6 is the beginning of the modeling chapters. The goal of ensemble methods is to combine the predictions from several base estimators built with a given learning algorithm in order to improve generalizability/robustness over a single estimator. Ensemble methods help reduce bias and/or variance. They cannot reduce noise. Averaging Ensemble Methods Build single estimators independently then average their predictions. On average, the combined estimator is better than the single estimator because the variance is reduced.

item.title: Fractionally Differentiated Features
item.description: Motivation Low signal to noise in financial time series due to arbitrage Standard stationary transformations like integer differentiation further reduce signal by removing memory Price series have memory because every value is dependent upon a long history of previous values Integer differentiated series, like returns, have a memory cut-off History is disregarded after a certain time window Once memory has been removed, sophisticated techniques to retrieve signal leads to false positives Stationarity vs Memory Dilemma Non-stationarity is a time series with an unstable mean In order to perform inferential analysis, researchers need invariant processes Changes in yields, returns on log prices or changes in volatility are invariant These transformations make the data series stationary while removing memory For signal processing, we rarely want to remove all the memory since the memory is the basis for the predictive model Equilibrium models need memory to determine how far price has drifted long-run expected value What is mimimum amount of differentiation that makes a time series stationary while preserving as much memory as possible?

item.title: Sample Weights
item.description: Chapter 4: Sample Weights Sample Weights Most financial time series literature and models assume IID processes Financial time series are NOT IID Overlapping outcomes for our labeling process will mean that our observations are also not IID We have overlapping outcomes when one period’s label and returns coincide with another intervals For a given time point t we may have several labels running concurrently. We need a some function to compute how many labels we have running per time step Uniqueness of label for each feature Bagging Classifiers and Uniqueness Assuming IID observations leads to oversampling In-bag observations will become redundant to each other and similar to out of bag observations Redundancy of draws makes the bootstram inefficient For RF, all trees in the forest will be similar copies of overfit decision tree Out of bag samples will be similar to in-bag samples but so out of bag accuracy will be overestimated You can put an upper limit on the number of random samples so as to reduce the chance of oversampling Sequential Bootstrap Resample sequentially until K distinct original samples appear What are we sampling here?

item.title: Data Structures and Algorithms: Stacks and Queues
item.description: Some review I did for a bunch of interviews with trading firms Linear Data Structures Data structures like Stacks, Queues, Dequeues and Lists are called linear because the items are ordered depending on how they are added and removed. When an item is added, it will stay in the same location until it is removed. Linear Structures have two ends: a left and a right. Stack Stacks insertion and removal logic is Last-in-First-out (LIFO).

item.title: Labeling
item.description: Motivation In chapter 2 we produced a matrix of financial features from unstructured data. Unsupervised learning algos can learn pattern from feature matrix. Supervised learning, however, requires that each row of feature matrix must be labeled with a target label column Y. Fixed Time-Horizon method In finance, ML papers all used fixed time horizon method. However, time bars do not have good statistical properties. Labels are applied regardless of the state of volatility of returns.

item.title: Financial Data Structures
item.description: Notes from Chapter 2: Advances in Financial Machine Learning Motivation Using someone else’s dataset means you will likely discover what is already known by other people. Ideally, you want to start with raw, unstructured data and process it to make it most informative to you. Four Types of Financial Data Fundamental Data Accounting data that is reported quarterly Information that is found in regulatory findings and business analytics You must confirm when data was released so that analysis uses information only after it was publicly available Backfilling data means assigning data a value even if the actual value was unknown at time Reinstating data means to amend previously issues data values Low frequency and extremely regularized.

item.title: Listed Volatility and Variance Derivatives
item.description: These are notes from the book Listed Volatility and Variance Derivatives by Yves Hilpisch. Additional notes are available in the notebooks at the bottom. Chapter 1 Derivatives Volatility and Variance Volatility and Variance Concepts Realized/Historical Volatility: Standard Deviations of log returns of financial time series Instantaneous Volatility: Volatility factor for a diffusion process Implied Volatility: volatility that if you plug into BSM model will give you the market observed price of an option If you take the square of these values you get the variance of them Annualized Variance is the result of variance times 252, the number of trading days in one year Volatility and Variance as asset class VIX represents 30-day variance swap VIX trading began in 2004 VIX options begain in 2006 EUREX launched futures on EUROSTOXX50 in 2005 2010 VSTOXX index options created 2014 variance futures contract for EURO Stoxx 50 Vol of Vol VVIX, VVSTOXX reflect 30-day expectations of volatility Volatility Trading Long VSTOXX Future: Hedge equity positions and hedge short realized vol strategy Short VSTOXX Future: Speculate mean reversion after vol strike, reduced vega exposure to long vega option portfolios Term Structure arbitrage: If carry trade possible, and contango, short front and long back month Relative value arbitrage: Trade against other volatility instruments Long OTM Calls: Market crash insurance Short ATM Calls: Expecting mean reversion after significant market volatility Long ATM Straddle: When VVOL is high, buy put-call with same ATM strike and if vol moves fast enough in one direction, you sell Variance Trading Long Variance Future: Variance is higher than expected.

item.title: Python Algo Trading Notes
item.description: Ito Calculus Calculus is useful for continuous process that are diferrentiable at every point from 0 to t. If your process is stochastic and has random jumps and fluctuations, you can not take the derivative of certain points along that line. For stochastic processes this is true and Ito calculua is one way to perform integration. Reimann Sums Numerical approximation of integral with a finite sum. Euler Discretization Discretization of continuous process and approximate numerical solution to a stochastic differential equation.

item.title: Shiva, Rumi, Cain, Abel
item.description: In Hindu mythology, Lord Shiva, is known as the destroyer. As a westerner, my mind immediately draws up dark images of violence,chaos, and bedlam. item.title: The Greatest Risk
item.description: “The greatest risk is not taking a risk”. These words stimulated something in my mind to the question: What unknown hazards am I accepting by not taking the risks that sit in front of me? Honestly, the question certainly charged a kind of zero-fucks courage. There is not one moment when you are not facing the unknown hazards of reality. And if this truly sets in you realize you just have to go for it at all times.

item.title: Trading the world
item.description: Ever since I read Adventure Capitalist and Investment Biker the idea that you could use trading as way to express ideas about the world has really captivated me. Maybe that sounds like bullshit since I’ve only really started to give real attention to it. So be it. No more. Now it is true and I am living it. The ideas that I want to express are my views about the direction of geopolitical relationships as well as the monetary relationships between nation states.

item.title: You, your way, and God
item.description: So many systems, masters, gurus, experts, programs, classes. So many people striving, pursuing, seeking. So much human energy into this question, this pursuit. Clearly there must be answers. Maybe. Maybe the answers found, problems solved are those of the seeker. Are they your problems? If not, how can they be your answers? Do you know what you are actually after? Do you know what you actually want? Or have you just settled for someone elses desires, someone else’s problem, someone else’s narration of their solution, some one else’s system?

item.title: Your own thoughts
item.description: Agency, competence, sovereignty, independence, self-sufficiency, freedom. A bunch of words. Abstractions that point to something outside of you. Defined in some book or by some other human. Seemingly common short-cuts we use to transact with other humans and ourself. I’m concerned when I use these abstractions with myself to compel behavior. It’s actually not just these words. Its almost many words for many different behaviors and outcomes. Why do I need words and abstractions to marshall my resources to ends that I find meaningful?

item.title: Start Again
item.description: In the twilight of my temporal youth, I decideded to start over. In some ways, I feel that my life has just started. When your mind is consumed with something, not doing/living that thing is a kind of painful dishonesty. My relationship with pain is perhaps different than most folks. I don’t like pain that leads to regrets. I welcome pain that leads to freedom, awareness and peace. So enough bullshit.

item.title: What is this?
item.description: You’ve landed on my site. This is an experiment. This is where I am posting updates and ideas that come to me. Where are we? How did we get here? I am a world citizen, currently based in Bali, Indonesia. I’ve spent most of my post-university years in Hawai’i and California with meaningful episodes in Beijing, NYC, Shanghai, and Bogota. In my past, I have done many things to make a living.
